questions.text: Compare the normality of 2 mM of HCI and 1 mM of H2SO4:
questions.solution:
Normality is a measure of the concentration of a solution that is expressed in terms of the number of equivalent weights of solute per liter of solution. The equivalent weight of a substance is its molar mass divided by its valency.

The valency of HCl is 1, so the normality of a 2 mM HCl solution is:

Normality = (Molarity * Valency)

Normality = (2 mM * 1)

Normality = 2 N

The valency of H2SO4 is 2, so the normality of a 1 mM H2SO4 solution is:

Normality = (Molarity * Valency)

Normality = (1 mM * 2)

Normality = 2 N

Therefore, the normality of a 2 mM HCl solution is the same as the normality of a 1 mM H2SO4 solution.

questions.text: DNA methylation is involved in all, Except:
questions.solution:
Option A: Chromatin remodeling involves conformational, or covalent changes of nucleosomes brought about by the actions of multiprotein complexes (such as the SW1/SNF complex). These changes alter gene transcription (turning it on or off, depending on specific conditions). Mutations affecting different proteins of these complexes are often found in cancer cells.

Chromatin remodeling often involves histone modifications & DNA methylation.

Option B: Eukaryotic mRNA synthesis results in a pre-mRNA precursor that contains extensive amounts of excess RNA (introns) that must be precisely removed by RNA splicing to generate functional, translatable mRNA composed of exonic coding and 5′ and 3′ noncoding sequences.

Splicing is the removal of introns from RNA accompanied by the joining of its exons. DNA methylation marks exons, so it plays an important role in splicing.

Spliceosome is the macromolecular complex responsible for precursor mRNA splicing. The spliceosome consists of at least five small nuclear RNAs (snRNA; U1, U2, U4, U5, and U6) and many proteins.

Option C: Gene silencing is the regulation of gene expression in a cell to prevent the expression of a certain gene. The predominant mechanism of gene silencing involves the methylation of DNA and subsequent recruitment of various binding proteins that preferably recognize methylated DNA.

Option D: Base excision repair: Repairs modified & altered bases, DNA Glycosylases recognize such bases, remove them by cleaving glycosidic bond, create abasic (apurinic) site, which remove by endonuclease and then gap is filled by DNAP & sealed by ligase. It does not require DNA methylation.

Mismatch repair is methylation directed repair & requires help of DNA methylation.

questions.text: All are true regarding telomerase, Except:
questions.solution:
The ends of each chromosome contain structures called telomeres. Telomeres consist of short TG-rich repeats. Human telomeres have a variable number of repeats of the sequence 5′-TTAGGG-3′, which can extend for several kilobases. The telomeres of normal cells shorten on repeated cell division, which may result in cell death.

The enzyme telomerase replicates telomeres and is often expressed in cancer cells, helping them to evade cell death.

Telomerase, a multisubunit RNA template containing complex related to viral RNA-dependent DNA polymerases (reverse transcriptases), is the enzyme responsible for telomere synthesis and thus for maintaining the length of the telomere. Since telomere shortening has been associated with both malignant transformation and aging, this enzyme has become an attractive target for cancer chemotherapy and drug development.

Option A: Telomerase has Reverse transcriptase activity (RNA-dependent DNA polymerases)

Option B: Telomerase found only in Eukaryotes

Option C: Telomerase maintain telomere length and so maintain chromosome length

Option D: DNA fidelity is not maintained, as there is no proofreading activity or repair mechanism associated with telomerase.

questions.text:
Enzymes involved in Gluconeogenesis:
1. Pyruvate kinase
2. PEP Carboxykinase
3. Pyruvate carboxylase
4. Hexokinase
Which of the following enzymes are involved in gluconeogenesis?
questions.solution:
Glycolysis & Gluconeogenesis share the same pathway but in opposite directions, except irreversible steps of glycolysis catalyzed by different enzymes in gluconeogenesis.

3 irreversible steps of glycolysis are: Step 1: Glucokinase or Hexokinase, Step 3: Phosphofructokinase, Step 10: Pyruvate kinase

Above three irreversible steps in glycolysis are catalyzed by 4 different enzymes in gluconeogenesis. Pyruvate carboxylase & Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (reverse step 10), Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase (reverse step 3), Glucose-6-phosphatase (step 1)

PEP - CK (Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase) & Pyruvate carboxylase are involved in gluconeogenesis only.

Pyruvate kinase & Hexokinase are involved in glycolysis only.


So option B is correct.

questions.text: Thermic effect of food is highest for:
questions.solution:
The production of heat by the body increases as much as 30% above the resting level during the digestion and absorption of food. This is called the thermic effect of food, or diet-induced thermogenesis. The thermic response to food intake may amount to 5%–10% of the total energy expenditure.

SDA for different foods:

For a food containing 25 g of protein, the heat production from the caloric value is 100 Cal (25 x 4 Cal). However, when 25 g protein is utilized by the body, 130 Cal of heat is liberated. The extra 30 Cal is the SDA of protein.

Likewise, consumption of 100 Cal of fat results in 113 Cal and 100 Cal of carbohydrate in 105 Cal, when metabolized in the body.

SDA for protein, fat and carbohydrate are 30%, 13% and 5%, respectively. Thus, proteins possess the highest SDA while carbohydrates have the lowest.

Option A: SDA for protein is 30%, highest

Option B: SDA for fat is 13%

Option C: SDA for carbohydrate is and 5%, lowest

Option D: SDA for mixed diet: For a mixed diet, the SDA is not an additive value of different foods but it is much less. The presence of fats and carbohydrates reduces the SDA of proteins. Fats are most efficient in reducing SDA of foodstuffs. For a regularly consumed mixed diet, the SDA is around 10%.

questions.text:
In vitamin B12 deficiency, which of the following enzymes will be involved?
1. Methionine synthase
2. Methyl malonyl CoA isomerase
3. Homocysteine synthase
4. Folate reductase
questions.solution:
Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase (Methyl malonyl-CoA isomerase), and methionine synthase are vitamin B12–dependent enzymes.

Methylmalonyl-CoA is formed as an intermediate in the catabolism of valine and by the carboxylation of propionyl-CoA arising in the catabolism of isoleucine, cholesterol, and rare fatty acids with an odd number of carbon atoms, or directly from propionate, a major product of microbial fermentation ruminants. It undergoes a vitamin B12–dependent rearrangement to succinyl-CoA, catalyzed by methylmalonyl-CoA mutase. The activity of this enzyme is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to an accumulation of methylmalonyl-CoA and urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid, which provides a means of assessing vitamin B12 nutritional status

The one-carbon fragment of methylene-tetrahydrofolate is reduced to a methyl group with release of dihydrofolate, which is then reduced back to tetrahydrofolate by dihydrofolate reductase. Thymidylate synthase and dihydrofolate reductase are especially active in tissues with a high rate of cell division. Methotrexate, an analog of 10-methyltetrahydrofolate, inhibits dihydrofolate reductase and is used in cancer chemotherapy.

Homocysteine synthase involved in synthesis of homocysteine, does not require vitamin B12.

So Option A is correct.

PCR is a method of amplifying a target sequence of DNA. The development of PCR has revolutionized the ways in which both DNA and RNA can be studied. PCR provides a sensitive, selective, and extremely rapid means of amplifying any desired sequence of DNA. Specificity is based on the use of two oligonucleotide primers that hybridize to complementary sequences on opposite strands of DNA and flank the target sequence.

The DNA sample is first heat denatured (>90°C) to separate the two strands of the template DNA containing the target sequence; the primers, added in excess, are allowed to anneal to the DNA (typically at 50-75°C) in order to generate the required template-primer complex. Subsequently, each strand is copied by a DNA polymerase, starting at the primer sites in the presence of all four dXTPs. The two DNA strands each serve as a template for the synthesis of new DNA from the two primers.

Repeated cycles of heat denaturation, annealing of the primers to their complementary sequences, and extension of the annealed primers with DNA polymerase result in the exponential amplification of DNA segments of defined length. Product DNA doubles with each PCR cycle. DNA synthesis is catalyzed by a heat-stable DNA polymerase purified from one of a number of different thermophilic bacteria, organisms that grow at 70 to 80°C. Thermostable DNA polymerases withstand short incubations at over 90°, temperatures required to completely denature DNA. These thermostable DNA polymerases have made automation of PCR possible. DNA sequences as short as 50 to 100 bp and as long as 10 kb can readily be amplified by PCR. Twenty cycles provide an amplification of 106 (ie, 220) and 30 cycles, 109 (230). Each cycle takes ≤5 to 10 minutes so that even large DNA molecules can be amplified fairly rapidly.

So the correct sequence is Denaturation → Annealing → Elongation, so option B is correct.

questions.text: CO2 elimination = 200, O2 consumed = 250, calculate respiratory quotient:
questions.solution:
Respiratory quotient [RQ] is measurement of the ratio of the volume of carbon dioxide produced: volume of oxygen consumed

So RQ here = 200/250 = 0.8

So option B is correct.

Respiratory quotient [RQ] is an indication of the mixture of metabolic fuels being oxidized,

Respiratory quotient [RQ] is highest for carbohydrates & lowest for alcohol.

questions.text: A patient presented with pallor and cyanosis with the following presentation. Ideal condition is:
questions.solution:
A patient presented with pallor and cyanosis with hyperpigmentation of the knuckles and palms is another common observation with B12 deficiency in children.

The hematologic manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency are similar to manifestations of folate deficiency. Irritability, hypotonia, developmental delay, developmental regression, and involuntary movements (predominantly coarse tremors) are the common neurologic symptoms in infants. Older children with vitamin B12 deficiency may show poor growth and poor school performance, whereas sensory deficits, paresthesias, peripheral neuritis, and psychosis are seen in adults. Hyperpigmentation of the knuckles and palms is another common observation with B12 deficiency in children.

Maternal B12 deficiency may also be an independent risk factor for fetal neural tube defects.

So Option B is correct.

questions.text: High anion gap acidosis is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
• Anion Gap is difference between measured cation & anions

AG = (Na+ + K+) – (Cl- + HCO3-)

  • Normal value: 12 + 2 mmol/l (10 – 14)
  • Indicate unmeasured anions like protein, phosphate, sulphates, organic acids etc
  • High anion gap most commonly associated with metabolic acidosis.
  • When only loss of HCO3- AG ↑ & When loss of HCO3- associated with ↑ reabsorption of Cl- (Hyperchloremia) or loss of Na+ & K+ also AG is normal
  • Clinically metabolic acidosis divided into High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) or normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA)

Option A: Renal failure leads to HAGMA, whereas Renal tubular acidosis leads to NAGMA.

Option B: DKA usually occurs in insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus in association with cessation of insulin or an intercurrent illness such as an infection, gastroenteritis, pancreatitis, or myocardial infarction, which increases insulin requirements temporarily and acutely, and is characterized by hyperglycemia, ketonemia, and a high-AG acidosis.

Option C: An increase in plasma l-lactate may be secondary to poor tissue perfusion (type A)-circulatory insufficiency (shock, cardiac failure), severe anemia, mitochondrial enzyme defects, and inhibitors (carbon monoxide, cyanide)-or to aerobic disorders (type B)-malignancies, nucleoside analogue reverse transcriptase inhibitors in HIV, diabetes mellitus, renal or hepatic failure, thiamine deficiency, severe infections (cholera, malaria), seizures, or drugs/toxins (biguanides, ethanol, and the toxic alcohols: ethylene glycol, methanol, or propylene glycol). Unrecognized bowel ischemia or infarction in a patient with severe atherosclerosis or cardiac decompensation receiving vasopressors is a common cause of lactic acidosis in elderly patients. Pyroglutamic acidemia may occur in critically ill patients

Option D: Salicylate intoxication in adults usually causes respiratory alkalosis or a mixture of high-AG metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis. Only a portion of the AG is due to salicylates. Lactic acid production is also often increased.
